Sweep.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to clean the dust, dirt etc from the floor or ground, using a brush with a long handle
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Bert swept the path in front of the house.
Will you sweep the leaves off the patio?
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to move things from a surface with a brushing movement
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: I swept the papers quickly into the drawer.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to force someone or something to move in a particular direction
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: The windsurfer was swept out to sea.
Jessie was swept along by the angry crowd.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: if a group of people or animals sweep somewhere, they quickly move there together
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: The crowd swept through the gates of the stadium.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: if winds, waves, fire etc sweep a place or sweep through, across etc a place, they move quickly and with a lot of force
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Ninety-mile per hour winds swept across the plains.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: if an idea, feeling, or activity sweeps a group of people or a place, it quickly becomes very popular or common
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: a wave of nationalism sweeping the country
the latest craze sweeping through the teenage population
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: if a feeling sweeps over you, you are suddenly affected by it
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: A feeling of isolation swept over me.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: if someone sweeps somewhere, they move quickly and confidently, especially because they are impatient or like to seem important
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: Eva swept into the meeting and demanded to know what was going on.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: to win an election easily and in an impressive way
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[8].exam: Herrera was swept into office on the promise of major reforms.
Nixon and Agnew swept to victory with 47 million votes.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[9].defi: to win all of the games in a series of games against a particular team
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[9].exam: Houston swept Orlando to become NBA champions.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[10].def: to form a long curved shape
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[10].exa: The hills swept down to the sea.
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[11].def: to look quickly at all of something
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[11].exa: The generalâ€™s eyes swept the horizon.
the beam from the lighthouse sweeping across the sea
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[12].def: to pull your hair back from your face
Sweep.translation[1].definitions[12].exa: Kerry swept her hair back into a ponytail.
Sweep.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a long swinging movement of your arm, a weapon etc
Sweep.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: With a single sweep of his sword, he cut through the rope.
Sweep.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: the act of cleaning a room with a long-handled brush
Sweep.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The kitchen needs a good sweep.
Sweep.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: a search or attack that moves over a large area
Sweep.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: He watched the helicopter make a sweep over the beach.
Sweep.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: a series of several games that one team wins against another team
